support_summary: AMFR (also known as gp78) is an E3 ubiquitin ligase that contains a VCP-interacting motif (VIM) and directly recruits VCP to the ER membrane to facilitate ERAD.

functions.cellular_process: AMFR (Autocrine Motility Factor Receptor), also known as gp78, is an E3 ubiquitin ligase anchored in the ER membrane. It plays a key role in ERAD by ubiquitinating misfolded proteins. AMFR contains a VCP-interacting motif (VIM) which allows it to directly recruit the VCP ATPase complex from the cytosol to the ER membrane. This recruitment is essential for the retrotranslocation (extraction) of the newly ubiquitinated ERAD substrates from the ER into the cytosol for subsequent degradation by the proteasome.
functions.effect_description: Functions as a critical ER-resident E3 ligase and a VCP recruitment factor that couples the ubiquitination of ERAD substrates to their VCP-mediated extraction from the ER.
biological_consequence: Misfolded protein in ER is recognized → AMFR/gp78 ubiquitinates the substrate → AMFR/gp78 recruits the VCP complex to the ER membrane via its VIM domain → VCP utilizes ATP hydrolysis to extract the ubiquitinated substrate from the ER → The substrate is delivered to the 26S proteasome for degradation.
specific_effects: AMFR/gp78 is an ERAD ubiquitin ligase that recruits VCP to the ER membrane.
The interaction is mediated by a VCP-interacting motif (VIM) within gp78.
The gp78-mediated ERAD pathway may utilize a VCP-Npl4 complex that is independent of Ufd1.
